abstract.p: Air Canada buys 14 passenger jets worth estimated $575 million from Airbus Industrie; airline is expected to spend $3 billion over next decade to replace about 100 aging jets (S)

block.p: Canada's dominant airline, Air Canada, has agreed to buy 14 passenger jets worth an estimated $575 million from the European consortium Airbus Industrie. Robert Milton, president and chief executive of Air Canada, said the dozen 160-seat A321's and two 112-seat A319's are the the first purchase in a renewal program to replace older-generation aircraft like the DC-9 and Boeing 737. Most of the planes will be delivered in 2002. With its takeover of Canadian Airlines earlier this year, Air Canada has 372 aircraft, 98 of them made by Airbus. The airline is expected to spend $3 billion over the next decade to replace about 100 aging jets.
